item.title: Wacky Windows Environment Variables
item.description: Introduction Picture this - you’ve been blessed with the task of dissecting a binary written in C++ that looks like the following: #include <iostream> using namespace std; void admin() { cout << "There is no DEMO - signs of an admin!"; } void user() { cout << "I see a DEMO variable - signs of a regular user"; } int main() { char* check; check = getenv("DEMO"); if (check != NULL) { user(); } else admin(); } What is it even doing, and is it possible to get to admin without being an admin?
